Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project is awarding annual renewable scholarships to academically talented, financially needy undergraduate engineering students. The first cohort consists of 15 scholarship students. The second year, the program is funding 25 Engineering Leadership Pathway Scholars (ELPS) consisting of new and continuing scholarship recipients. The program size grows each year to a maximum of 35 scholarships. Scholars are recruited from sophomore and junior courses as well as community colleges and have completed the first two semesters of calculus. Scholarship recipients form a group of students engaged in personal leadership development activities in parallel with their academic development. Students develop their own visions of leadership and emerge with personal and professional goals, which help them make the best of their own talents as well as be prepared to tackle the challenges that face the nation's technical leaders. Eligible engineering disciplines include aerospace, chemical, civil, computer/software, electrical, materials, mechanical, industrial, and general.
INTELLECTUAL MERIT: The project provides the support services and activities to motivate and prepare students to complete the B.S. degree with attitudes, knowledge and skills to be leaders in the 21st century workforce and to pursue graduate degrees. The four-year program is generating 55 to 60 future leaders who can serve as role models for other students. An additional outcome is a better understanding of the characteristics that define leadership and effective programs to develop those characteristics. The ELPS program is housed in the Engineering Student Success Center, which provides meeting space, study carrels, computer facilities, advising, and professional development guidance. ELP Scholars also benefit from tutoring, workshops, field trips, as well as interaction with faculty, graduate students participating in research, and practitioners.
BROADER IMPACTS: The ELPS program is recruiting a diverse applicant pool (many of whom are underrepresented in STEM or who are first generation in college), and providing U.S. industry with engineers who have practiced leadership skills. The ELPS program is meant to serve as a model for leadership development throughout the College of Engineering. Development of activities with three feeder community colleges involves community college students in leadership development. Lessons learned are being disseminated through conferences, presentations, and archived articles, and used to expand the ELPS program to all interested engineering students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
From 2010 to 2016 the San Jose State University (SJSU) Engineering Leadership Pathway Scholars (ELPS) program provided support services and activities to motivate and prepare students to complete the B.S. degree with attitudes, knowledge, and skills to be leaders in the 21st century workforce and to pursue graduate degrees. Through exposing students to complexities of engineering leadership and the many potential paths of an engineering career, helping students to create and implement a leadership development plan, and involving them in shaping the ELPS program, the project team worked to develop and reinforce qualities to lay the foundation for future leaders. The program served all engineering majors in the college (aerospace, biomedical, chemical, civil, computer, electrical, industrial and systems, materials, mechanical, and software). 

The objectives of the ELP Scholars project were to:

  1. Effectively support upper division students so that they graduate on time, with the technical background, performance record, and motivation needed to pursue graduate degrees or enter the workforce. The three year graduation rate (post-transfer) or six-year graduation rate (for first-time frosh) should exceed 80% for students in this program.
  2. Institutionalize activities that promote and reinforce attitudes and skills essential to engineering and personal leadership by including all College of Engineering scholarship recipients in the leadership development activities.
  3. Create a cohort model for the ELP Scholars as a community of learners who support each other’s individual and common goals

The ELPS program developed an ongoing suite of leadership development activities. Each student was matched with a faculty mentor who met with the student in person and virtually to support the leadership development. The program provided training for faculty mentors to discuss best practices. In addition, the PI tracked each student and ensured that the students were taking classes that progressed them toward graduation in a timely manner and provided additional support such as tutoring if needed.

The program offered two leadership breakfasts per semester at which industry representatives shared breakfast with the students and then discussed topics related to leadership in a panel format. Each semester included a field trip, three Munch with the Mentor events, a cohort-building social event such as a hike or bowling, opportunities to attend career presentations, and individual interactions with their mentors.  For example, the Career Center held workshops for ELPS students on writing a resume, creating a LinkedIn profile, interviewing, and networking. Once a representative from LinkedIn came to campus and showed students how employers mine LinkedIn data to find potential employees. We used a learning management system and Facebook to link students together and create a more cohesive cohort. Students were given travel grants to attend professional meetings and to participate in a summer leadership program in Taiwan.

Other activities included self-reflection such as development of a leadership plan and Myers-Briggs analysis. We held workshops on how to dress for success and how to network before students attended the College of Engineering awards banquet and the scholarship luncheon. To provide additional leadership experience, we created an ELPS Steering Committee consisting of mentors and students, which was responsible for planning the events each semester. We also engaged current ELPS participants in interviewing candidates for future scholarships. During the last year we held a reunion of previous ELPS alumni and current ELPS students. It was a great opportunity for networking and informal mentoring.

To institutionalize the program we invited all scholarship students in the College of Engineering, as well as student engineering organization leadership, to attend all ELPS events on a space available basis.

The project met all of its goals.  We had a diverse group of participants (28% female and 72% male), (18 white, 13 Asian, 13 Hispanic, 1 Black, 1 Pacific Islander). Out of the 46 students that enrolled in the program, 42 graduated (91%).  This is 18 percentage points higher than the SJSU engineering transfer student graduation rate and 40 percentage points higher than SJSU engineering students that start as freshmen.  The 4 students who did not earn a degree left because of family issues or medical problems.  Almost all of the students participated in undergraduate research or an internship or both. Nine students pursued a minor and 10 participated in the SJSU College of Engineering summer overseas leadership development program called the Global Technology Initiative. Many were leaders in student organizations and were recognized for their accomplishments by university awards and additional scholarships funded by industry and professional organizations. The average GPA of students who graduated from the program is 3.52 on a scale of 4. All graduated students are in the workforce and are  already showing leadership in their companies. Ten are in graduate school, and one of those students is pursuing a PhD.
